summary: Protein is the third most important nutrient, after oxygen and water, being the main functional and structural component of all cells. Protein is the backbone of all metabolic functions. Proteins are chains of amino acids, hence, amino acids are the building blocks of all cells. There are 20 amino acids, from which only 10 are essential (Arginine, Histidine, Isoleucine, Leucine, Lysine, Methionine, Phenylalanine, Threonine, Tryptophan, Valine). Protein quality of food varies, according to the essential amino acid content. Protein with all essential amino acids is complete, the rest is incomplete. Thus, it is important to focus on complete protein foods
uses: Mentality (Attention, Concentration, Decision making, Learning, Memory, Reasoning, Speaking, and Stress problems)
warnings: Absorption impaired by sedentarism, alcohol, sugar, tobacco, caffeine, stress, pharmaceutical drugs

name: Fatty acid (Fat)

references.credit: Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Fats, Lipids And Oils
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Lipids
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary fat: Total fat and Fatty acids

summary: Fatty acids or fats are lipids that serve as secondary energy source, when glucose is absent, along with other important functions. Fatty acids are classified as unsaturated fatty acids (fluid at low temperature and unstable) and saturated fatty acids (solid at low temperature and stable). alpha-Linolenic acid (an omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid) and Linoleic acid (an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid) are the only essential fatty acids.
uses: Mentality (Attention, Concentration, Decision making, Learning, Memory, Reasoning, Speaking, and Stress problems)
warnings: Unsaturated fats, because they are unstable, are degraded light and destroyed by heat

Fats from processed (refined) foods are forcely hydrogenated to become stable and last during transportation and in food stores. This makes them turn intro trans fat, which are toxic for our body. Trans fats, among others, increase triglyceride levels (Blood lipid and fat storage) and damage our body, hence, they must be eliminated completeley

name: Carbohydrate

references.credit: Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Carbohydrates
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary Carbohydrates: Sugars and Starches

summary: Carbohydrates are the most common source of energy. Carbohydrates are chains of sugar units called saccharides and are classified based on their structure: simple carbohydrates (sugars) and complex carbohydrates (starches and fiber). Glucose, a sugar, is the universal energy supply used by cells which can also be obtained from fat and amino acids. Thus, sugars are non-essential nutrients. Fiber is the only essential type of carbohydrates
warnings: Excess sugars bring damage to blood vessels, bones, brain, DNA, heart, intestines, kidneys, liver, muscles, pancreas, stomach

Excess sugars may lead to autoimmune disease, cancer, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, high blood cholesterol, osteoporosis, obesity, Alzheimer's disease, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), insulin resistance, and many others among them

name: Fiber

references.credit: Elson Haas M. MD, Healthy.net, Building Blocks Of Nutrition: Carbohydrates
Mayo clinic, Dietary fiber: Essential for healthy diet
Jennifer J. Otten, Jennifer Pitzi Hellwig, Linda D. Meyers, Editors, 'Dietary Reference Intakes: The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements', Dietary Carbohydrates: Sugars and Starches

summary: Fiber is the indigestable form of carbohydrates found in the skin of fruits and vegetables and in the bran (shell) of seeds and grains. The body cannot digest, nor absorb fiber, hence, it is not required by cells on their own. Yet, it is required for the overall system functions
warnings: Excess impairs Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Zinc absorption
Excess causes diarrhea
